abstract: Federal regulators, after years of delay, issue new rules on executive pay that limit how large banks can pay their top managers; restrictions on banker bonuses, intended to stymie risky investment bets, would make top earners wait at least four years to receive parts of their pay; rules grew out of 2010 Dodd-Frank law in response to criticism over Wall Street's compensation practices following 2008 crisis.

headline.print_headline: After 6 Years, a Plan Targets Wall Street Pay
headline.main: Wall St. Regulators Propose Stricter Pay Rules for Bankers

keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

snippet: The new rules would make executives wait at least four years to receive portions of their bonuses and force banks to find ways to claw back bonuses.
lead_paragraph: The new rules would make executives wait at least four years to receive portions of their bonuses and force banks to find ways to claw back bonuses.
